title: Baja Med
text:
Baja Med is a term conceived by Chef Miguel Ángel Guerrero that refers to <a href="fusion%20cuisine">fusion cuisine</a> of <a href="Mexican%20cuisine">Mexican cuisine</a>, such as <a href="chicharr%C3%B3n">chicharrón</a> and <a href="cotija%20cheese">cotija cheese</a>, with those of <a href="Mediterranean%20cuisine">Mediterranean</a>, such as olive oil, and <a href="Asian%20cuisine">Asian cuisine</a>, such as lemongrass. Baja Med dishes showcase the fresh produce and seafood of <a href="Baja%20California">Baja California</a>.
Ingredients.
The cuisine features the fresh produce of the state. This includes fresh seafood from the port of <a href="Ensenada%2C%20Baja%20California">Ensenada</a> such as mussels, oysters, clams and shrimp, and blue tuna; miniature vegetables from the fields south of Ensenada, olives from the winemaking region of the <a href="Guadalupe%2C%20Baja%20California">Guadalupe Valley</a> just northeast of Ensenada, dates from <a href="San%20Ignacio%2C%20Baja%20California%20Sur">San Ignacio</a> and tomatoes and strawberries from the <a href="San%20Quint%C3%ADn%2C%20Baja%20California">San Quintin</a> Valley. Additional ingredients include red lobster, manta rays, sea cucumbers and <a href="salicornia">salicornia</a>, a succulent that grows in sand dunes. 
Examples of dishes.
Examples of Baja Med dishes include:
Chefs and restaurants.
Baja Med cuisine is a feature of the various restaurants of La Querencia and La Esperanza from Miguel Ángel Guerrero, other <a href="Tijuana">Tijuana</a> restaurants such as Food Garden, and Manzanilla in the city of <a href="Ensenada%2C%20Baja%20California">Ensenada</a>. In <a href="Bonita%2C%20California">Bonita, California</a>, between <a href="San%20Diego">San Diego</a> and Tijuana, Plascencia's Romesco features the cuisine. 
Valle de Guadalupe.
In the <a href="Valle%20de%20Guadalupe">Valle de Guadalupe</a> wine country near Ensenada, chef Jaír Tellez's restaurant Laja is renowned for the cuisine, as are his restaurants Contramar and Merotoro in <a href="Mexico%20City">Mexico City</a>. Diego Hernández heads up Corazón de Tierra in the <a href="Valle%20de%20Guadalupe">Valle de Guadalupe</a>, rated by William Reed Business Media (the "San Pellegrino survey") as one of Latin America's 50 best restaurants, also rick baylessand his trendy Leña Brava in Chicago. while chef <a href="Javier%20Plascencia">Javier Plascencia</a> is present with his Finca de Altozano, and <a href="Drew%20Deckman">Drew Deckman</a> with Deckman's en el Mogor.
